title: Thursday, 6th June 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Good morning.

VV75 bonjour
nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:04am

And firstly, thoughts & prayers to all City pictures desks.

BE11:05am

Entertainment One, the company behind Peppa Pig, insisted on Thursday that the creative head of its film and television studio would stay at the group, following a report that he was in talks to leave the role.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Shares in the London-listed film and television production company fell 17 per cent on Wednesday after Variety reported that Mark Gordon — a Hollywood veteran who has produced blockbusters including Saving Private Ryan and Steve Jobs — was being pushed out of his role after disagreements with senior managers.

Markkus morning
AMALtd morning
VV75 it was a hefty move after that Variety "article"
BE11:06am

Okay, so be careful not to illustrate the story with Mark Gordon the Governor of Wyoming.

BE11:06am

Or Mark Gordon of Chuck E Cheese.

OnYourRight Morning all
11:06 am
BE11:07am

Maybe cross-check IMDB for the right one?

BE11:07am

BE11:07am

Ah.

VV75 it's like John smith
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Anyway. I think the original story yesterday came from Deadline Hollywood,

BE11:09am

https://deadline.c...sident-1202627437/

BE11:10am

Mark Gordon is settling out and will be leaving his position as president of Entertainment One, Deadline has confirmed. ....

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Though Variety might've published something rumour-ish earlier. Anyway, all history now. What exactly's happening?

Shinshin I get you might have duplicate names behind camera, but I thought all actors were obliged to have a unique name to get an equity/guild card
moonshot Any broker insight into Mike Ashley's latest foray into GAME Digital?
BE11:12am

Here's Citi on everyone's favourite Canadian turkey factory.

BE11:13am

There appears to be a mismatch between what the article is actually reporting i.e. Mark Gordon’s role may change, and the market reaction. The market appears to have jumped to the conclusion that Mark Gordon is set to exit ETO altogether (based on the negative tone and commentary on internal relations and, perhaps, inaccurate conclusion in the article that suggests there could be a complete departure). The comment made by the company implies an exit is not on the cards -‘very important part of the eOne team now and in the future’ – this is not a statement we would expect if an announcement of his departure was imminent. ETO acquired MGC for a total of $342m. The market has wiped more than this off the value of ETO. Mark Gordon is certainly well respected in the industry, with an impressive track record, but even if he was to leave, this appears an overreaction given IP ownership sits with ETO (given its full ownership of Mark Gordon Company).

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The role of President of Film, TV and Digital has been a joint role with Steve Bertram and the integration of film, TV and MGC together into one unit over the past 12-18 months means the division is much larger now. While reports of internal tension are not ideal, given the underperformance of scripted TV in FY19 and Mark Gordon’s background in scripted content production, it makes sense if the role change is one in which Mark Gordon can focus his efforts on the production side of the business (in scripted) and Steve Bertram is responsible for the corporate/financial part of the role.

VV75 any broker comments on Carnivals exposure to Cuba because of the US ban on travel there?
BE11:14am

A Clean Exit is Not That Easy – When ETO increased its holding of Mark Gordon Company to 100% last year it also reset the clock on the contract with Mark Gordon. He signed a new 5 year [exclusive] deal with ETO with a 2 year extension option. There are at least 4 years left to run on that contract which means jumping ship and working for other content producers is unlikely to be possible. Mark Gordon also received 10.8m shares in ETO at the time [worth £38m at today’s price].

BE11:15am

And more brief, from Numis.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Mark Gordon may change his duties to focus more on where his interests lie ie production rather than admin but is staying within ETO in our view. BUY - shares now trade on adj EV/EBITDA of sub 10x for CY20E at yesterdays' close, which is very attractive given macro content positives and ETO positioning to higher quality content. Multiples based SOTP is 573p.

BE11:16am

And Canaccord, seeming to have had similar conversations as the Citi team.

Pharma Anyone have any thoughts about what might happen now Fiat-Renault has been called off. Presumably FiatChrysler still believe they are sub-scale, and need a partner.
BE11:16am

Given Mark Gordon’s background in film and TV production (Speed, Day After Tomorrow, Saving Private Ryan, Grey’s Anatomy, Ray Donovan, Criminal Minds, Designated Survivor, The Rookie), we believe that a more likely scenario is that Mark Gordon is shifting towards focusing more on production activity (which is his specialty), rather than on his corporate executive responsibilities. Whether this means there will be a change in designation is unclear. However, we very much doubt that Mark Gordon is leaving the firm altogether

11:16 am
BE11:16am

A compelling buying opportunity: Given the key-man risk attached to Mark Gordon, the stock price fell nearly 17% on the news, to 350p. The shares are currently trading at 8.5x EV/F21 EBITDA, which we believe is a highly attractive entry point for investors, particularly for those who may have missed the upswing in the share price over the past two years. Entertainment One has one of the most consistent financial track records in our coverage, having grown EBITDA at double-digit rates organically through F2015-F2019, and in our view is on track to do so again in F2020. This, together with the strong balance sheet with sub 2x leverage (1.7x as of F2019), makes this a key pick in the media sector.

BE11:18am

Wonder if, due to this stoosh, we'll start mentioning Mark Gordon when talking about E1 rather than sticking Peppa bloody Pig in the lead the whole time?

BE11:18am

Probably not.

11:18 am
Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 402.00, up 52 (+14.86%), High: 411.20, Low: 391.60, Volume: 2.33m
undefined
BE11:19am

And to the real story of the morning, French cars.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Renault down 8%-ish live after FCA withdraws.

Ethnick surprised not to see Auto Trader +5% today... Great results and a good beat.
BE11:20am

And not, seemingly, a politically motivated. Paris still keen. FCA, however, not.

Markkus Fiat discovers it's really dealing with the French government...
BE11:22am

Though FCA blames "political conditions in France" as a reason for decision so we can see the cold hand of interference on this.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

What happens next? Renault merge with Nissan?

BE11:24am

With French government interference confirmed, that surely looks less likely this morning than it did a month ago.

BE11:24am

Here's Jefferies.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

According to WSJ, Nissan representatives declined to support the proposed merger while the State demanded guarantees about continuation of the Renault-Nissan Alliance post-merger. Considering how much the Alliance has stalled operationally in past years and Nissan’s priority for a stand-alone turnaround, we question why the State is placing such priority on the Alliance to the detriment of Renault’s strategic options. This also follows the role of the State enabling Nissan in 2015 to effectively regain control of its Board and dilute Renault’s representation (RAMA terms post implementation of double voting).

BE11:25am

The 10.6% outperformance of RNO shares since the proposal shifted the ratio 2.3% in favour of Renault shareholders or c.€1.5bn, an amount we think was within a range of acceptable outcomes for FCA. While some investors argued Renault was undervalued, we saw no reason why, in a merger offer, FCA should “correct” Renault’s chronic discount which largely reflects below industry average auto margins and misallocation of capital to Nissan vs returns. While there are a number of reasons to expect closer cooperation with Nissan over time esp in NA with FCA, there was also material upside to seeing Nissan as a financial asset whose value could be realised at some point, at least in part.

BE11:25am

Yes, but what next?

Shinshin PSA-Renault champion nationale ?
11:25 am
BE11:25am

• FCA’s decision looks radical but the statement was carefully worded, thanking all corporates involved. This could leave the door open to further discussion esp if FCA already make some concessions to the State.
• Other discussions. Both parties have acknowledged the need for scale or M&A and may pursue other opportunities. If Nissan was an obstacle PSA-FCA discussions could resume. We tend to see more opportunities for FCA given its more global exposure and NA market share. There is still a solid fit with PSA although probability looks low.

BE11:26am

Or if you prefer, here's UBS.

BE11:26am

Renault’s willingness to reach a deal (either with Nissan earlier this year or FCA) seems to be delayed for the foreseeable future. In our recent detailed synergy analysis report. we estimated the value the of the synergies for Renault shareholders at €15-20/share. Given the share price reaction since the announcement last week, the market appears not to have been reflecting that these would materialise. On that basis, and given the low valuation for the stub (see valuation section below), we see limited material downside risk to the share price near term. As regards FCA, we continue to see some rationale for a deal with PSA.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

From an operating standpoint, we expect a difficult H1 as some key markets continue to slow down [Russia] or still have a difficult base [Turkey and Iran].

BE11:28am

Upcoming new launches should support volume growth from H2/Q4 onwards [Clio in Europe, Arkana in Russia, etc.]. For the FY, we expect a slightly declining profitability margin [6.3% to 6.1%].

BE11:28am

We think it will be a stretch for RNO to deliver on its positive FCF guidance given the expected spike in capex this year [dedicated EV platform]. Therefore, RNO has limited scope to offset the Nissan divi cut by its core FCF [c-26% impact on RNO DPS].

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Citi also talking about Renault returning to fair value.

BE11:28am

In the backdrop of a merger proposal from FCA (which looked extremely accretive for Renault's earnings), we did not think it was appropriate to change our recommendation (as the market would look through the near term headwinds and start to price-in some of the synergies). However, given FCA's withdrawal we revise our target price to €56 (derived on the basis of the long-term average EV/EBITDA less capex multiple, 1.7x), and downgrade to Neutral.

AMALtd FCA using a good excuse... Synergies are in 90% of the case killing jobs, just be frank about it...
BE11:29am

While Renault is a leader in EVs its ICE fleet is not particularly efficient; 2) Renault may follow Nissan with a dividend cut 3) We forecast a group EBIT margin of 5.4% in 2020, and 5.8% in 2021 (vs Factset consensus of 5.7% and 6.1% respectively); and 4) Excluding any dividends received from Associates, we expect Renault to generate negative free cash flow in 2019 and 2020.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Renault is a leader in EVs? It it?

BE11:29am

Sorry, I know nothing about cars.

BE11:30am

Where to from here with Nissan?

The situation with Nissan is tricky to gauge. The fact that Renault kept its Alliance-partner in the dark about its negotiations with FCA will likely have irked Nissan - and it will not have helped what seemed to be an already strained relationship. However, with a new Chairman expected to be announced at Nissan in the coming weeks, we believe the focus of both companies will return to securing the future of the Alliance. We don't think that needs to involve a full merger (overly complicated with limited incremental benefit given significant industrial cooperation already) but more simply a rebalancing of the cross-shareholdings

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Groupe PSA could still be FCA's white-knight.

At an FCA share price above €10, PSA could not make the numbers work and hence stepped away. They could absolutely return to the fold when the situation gets more attractive - in terms of both ability to negotiate with unions and valuation.

BE11:36am

Auto Trader reported a solid set of FY19 results with a slight beat on both ARPR and forecourts with a reassuring FY20 outlook for the trade business, although we believe this is largely priced in given the stock has already rallied 29% YTD (+16% vs Stoxx Media).
Overall FY19 revenues of £355.1m were c.1% ahead of GSe and company-compiled consensus, and EBIT of £243.7m was 2% ahead with margins of 68.6%, up 160bp yoy (GS/consensus: 67.6%/68.0%). EPS of 21p was c.6% ahead of expectations, partly driven by a profit on disposal. The positive surprise was ARPR which grew 8.6% yoy (GSe+7.8%) to £1844 (+£149), implying 8.5% growth in 2H19 (vs 9.1% in 1H). The ARPA beat was driven by stock which declined 15% (implying c.22% in 2H vs -30% in 1H), less than our expectation of 32%, while price contributed 34% vs GSe 33% (36% in 1H) and product contributed 81%. The product growth was driven by further growth in penetration of the Advanced and Premium packages (as a percentage of listings) to 19% vs 15% at the end of 1H19, although dealers taking Managing Products decreased to 3,200 vs 3,300 at the end of 1H19. The number of forecourts was up 0.2% yoy (up 0.7% vs 1H19 end), compared to guidance of broadly stable (GSe/consensus -0.6% yoy). Consumer Services was broadly in line 6% yoy while Manufacturer & Agency revenues grew 17.8%, implying 19% growth in 2H (vs 28% in 1H) and compares to guidance of tempered growth in 2H.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

For FY20, the company has guided to another strong year of ARPR growth (GSe £136 /cons: £141), driven by the product lever (although below 2019), with similar absolute contribution from price, partly offset by a slight decline in stock (although better than 2019), which we view as reassuring. We expect the company to provide more colour on the B2B JV with Cox Automotive and the monetisation of the new car product from FY20. The guidance for retailer forecourt numbers was better than expected at flat yoy (GSe/consensus: -0.5%). Consumer services is expected to improve, similar to 2H, compared to current consensus of -0.4% yoy. Manufacturer & Agency revenue is however expected to decline in 1H due to the challenges facing OEMS and their agencies while we also note tough comps (1H19: 27.8% yoy). Operating costs are expected to grow LSD – MSD (GSe/cons: 3%/2%).

Tom Dalgleish Sorry I'm late
BE11:37am

And Credit Suisse.

BE11:37am

AutoTrader FY19 results solid, outlook mixed – AUTO's scheduled FY19 results this morning included revenues and operating profit +1% and +2% vs cons respectively. Whilst FY19 results were modestly ahead of consensus expectations, they were only marginally ahead of CSe. We believe that buy-side expectations were likely ahead of sell-side. As such we see this print as solid but no better. We see outlook as mixed: expectations for further stock declines in FY20 and a tough outlook for manufacturer and agency but further strong growth in product. We see no clear upgrade to FY20 consensus expectations from guidance (group only "confident" of meeting its growth expectations) which we believe the shares likely need given the strong run in the shares.

■ Group level +2% vs cons: Group level revenues of £355.1m were +1.1% vs consensus £351.3m (CSe £354.5m) on YoY growth of +8% (vs cons +6.4%, CSe +7.4%). Operating profit was £243.7m,. +2% vs cons £239.0m (CSe £241.0m) on a margin of 69% (cons and CSe 68.0%). Further down the P&L basic EPS was 21.0p, vs cons 19.7p (CSe 20.0p) and the dividend per share was 6.7p vs cons 6.6p.

red @OnYourRightcare home industry an excellent cash cow. so targeted by PE loaded with debt which makes the first trip up fatal. speaking to doctors over here, a very worthwhile business in eastern europe, where the switch from family care to outsourcing is just kicking off.
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Outlook mixed with no clear upgrade – We see outlook as mixed with guidance for further stock declines in FY20 and a tougher than expected outlook in Manufacturer and Agency with guidance for "strong" product growth, albeit below FY19 levels.
Detail – New year has "started well". ARPR is expected to be "strong" underpinned by product albeit product is expected to be below the "exceptional" levels of FY19 (CSe +4.9ppts FY20 vs +7.1ppts in FY19) price will be "consistent" (CSe +3ppts FY20 vs +3ppts in FY19) and stock "slightly down" (CSe +1ppts for FY20). Forecourts are expected to be flat in FY20 (CSe -1%). Consumer Services "improved" in 2H which the group expects to "continue" (CSe flat in FY20). Finally Manufacturer and Agency is expected to "decline" in 1H20 (CSe +13% for FY20).

BE11:42am

 Cost savings: 1) Aviva has announced £300m cost savings by 2022 which should support the EPS momentum; however, we believe that the issue with Aviva is more about fixing the debt leverage and strategy of the group rather than supporting EPS growth through cost savings which are short term in nature rather long term.
 Reiterating debt leverage reduction: 2) Management reiterated its intention to de-lever by £1.5bn by 2022 and flagged that the 2019-2021 outlook for cash inflows to center is comparable to 2016-2018 (which was £8bn); however, there is limited clarity so far as to what will be the make-up of the cash flows as the organic cash flows are considerably lower than cash flows achieved in 2016-2018.
 Reiterating dividend policy: 3) Aviva reiterated its progressive dividend policy which in our view is covered by organic cash flows and thus we weren’t expecting a dividend cut.
 Split of UK life and UK P&C: 4) UK life and UK P&C business to be split but there is limited clarity as to what are the positives/negatives from such a split.
 Although today’s announcement should support EPS momentum, we note that there are limited details around cash flow generation or strategy update, which in our view are the key concerns for investors at the moment.

Tom Dalgleish UBER has done a recovery speaking of cars

The trading update is dull so I'll ignore that bit.

red @sproutwas about to say despite any rent curbs the mkt there is booming
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Barclays:

BE11:43am

The company has announced a £300m cost target (net of inflation – absolute cost saves in excess of £300m) through to 2022, reducing its absolute cost based from c£4bn to £3.7bn, a 7.5% cost reduction. If these costs fell to the bottom line, it would add c6p to EPS through to 2022, equivalent to c50% of our EPS growth. While this is unlikely to lead to positive earnings revisions, it will give increased confidence on the ability of the company to deliver on current consensus estimates (mid-single digit EPS growth). The company has also reiterated its commitment to a progressive dividend and £1.5bn of debt leverage, and stated trading year to date is broadly consistent with 2018.

While expectations were modest going into today (the company is hosting a more in-depth analyst day on 20th November 2019 when we expect more detailed targets), the comments on the cost saves, trading update, dividend and de-leveraging should support estimates and the stock. Aviva is trading on 7.0x our 2019 operating EPS target (of 58.5p) and a 7.5% FY19 dividend yield, and with increased confidence on the company hitting our estimates (re-based lower by the new CEO in March), we reiterate our Overweight rating.

11:44 am

BE11:45am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

The Berlin Senate is considering introducing a 5 year rent freeze (a.k.a. Mietendeckel) from January 2020, according to numerous press articles yesterday, such as rbb24. Details. The articles cite a draft copy of a proposal that has been drawn up by the Berlin SPD and is set to be presented to the Berlin Senate on 18 June. According to the articles, under the SPD proposals rental increases could still be pushed through when properties are modernised. It is important to note that the press articles highlight the debate over whether rental law is within the remit of the federal government, and that according to the CDU parliamentary group a rent freeze would be at risk of being challenged by the Constitutional Court. We note a potential rent freeze has already been talked about since February (e.g. BBC dated 26 February 2019).Context. Rental protests in Berlin continue to be a focus for investors. We recently collated details and management commentary, see our report dated 2 April.Our view. Increasingly low property yields on German residential property (and Berlin assets in particular) mean that owners of these assets are reliant on organic rental growth and modernisation-driven uplifts to drive a total return that is sufficiently higher to sustain their current valuations around NAV. We have been taking the view that some of the debated measures around German residential property are very low probability extreme bear cases, and therefore we have stuck with our Overweight recommendation on the three main German residential stocks we cover (D Wohnen, LEG and Vonovia). A potential long-term rent freeze is arguably a more significant concern; not only does the likelihood of this seem higher, it could also reduce capital values as much or even more than other measures, we argue.Berlin or Germany-wide? So far the public discontent has been concentrated mainly in Berlin, which makes stocks such as Deutsche Wohnen most exposed. But we think equity markets will be concerned about potential contagion, which would affect peers such as LEG and Vonovia.

BE11:51am

[W]e highlight ING's view that a cross border deal in the without banking union only offers 1 out of 3 potential benefits i.e., cost synergies without capital or liquidity synergies. At a recent conference (3rd June ’19), ING’s CEO reiterated that there is limited logic for cross border EU bank mergers as long as the bloc’s banking union is incomplete which leads us to take the view that a deal is unlikely in the near term. As such, a dilutive acquisition by ING is very unlikely but is the biggest risk to our investment thesis. A transaction with CBK only offers limited cost synergies given ING’s digital strategy and requires revenue synergies as well as regulatory capital relief from a reduction in ING's capital stack which we do not foresee as likely.

French Connection has agreed with the Takeover Panel that any discussions in relation to an offer for the Company may take place within the context of a formal sale process (as referred to in the Code) in order to enable conversations with parties interested in making such a proposal to take place on a confidential basis. Accordingly, the Takeover Panel has granted a dispensation from the requirements of Rules 2.4(a), 2.4(b) and 2.6(a) of the Code such that any interested party participating in the formal sale process will not be required to be publicly identified as a result of this announcement and will not be subject to the 28 day deadline referred to in Rule 2.6(a), for so long as it is participating in the formal sale process.

UBS did the numbers yesterday.

Carnival PLC (CCL:LSE): Last: 3,849, down 27 (-0.70%), High: 3,902, Low: 3,841, Volume: 151.75k
BE12:11pm

Cuba is about 1% of Carnival's FY'19 deployment and closer to 2% in FY'20. Carnival is giving $100 on-board credit if passengers keep their current sailing, $50 on-board credit if they move to another itinerary and a full refund if they cancel. We believe CCL's Cuba bookings may not be as sticky as Royal's because they are offering a much lower incentive to keep their current itinerary. So Carnival may have more passengers that cancel, but Cuba is less than half percent of deployments in 2019. Therefore, Carnival may be expecting that even if they have to re-sell close-in Bahamas cruises on the same ship, they may expect to sell at a discount less than 50% of the previous booking. If CCL can re-sell that half percent of capacity at a -40% discount, that could be -20bps drag to yield and around $0.05 to EPS.

12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

For Norwegian, Cuba is 3-4% of full year deployment. Royal Caribbean's 2-3% of deployment.

BE12:12pm

For 2020, we don't expect much Cuban inventory has been sold at this point, so the cruise lines won't have to compensate passengers for cancelled calls to Cuba. Q1 may be the quarter most likely to see impact in 2020. Q1 typically has the highest deployment to the Caribbean — it was 45% of Q1 this year for CCL, 59% for NCLH, and 73% for RCL. H1 would see majority of the impact and second half would have easier comps given dislocation this year. But the combined EPS impact in 2020 seems likely to be less than the EPS impact for 2019. Given the abruptness of the changes and the currently unfolding responses from the cruise lines and from passengers, these scenarios are preliminary and we have not yet adjusted company EPS ests.
